name: Avoid Tables without Primary Key (SQL)
description: This metric displays the list of tables without Primary Key constraints
output:
Associated to each violation, the following information is provided:
- The number of violation occurrences
- Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in the source code
rationale:
Data integrity refers to the accuracy, consistency, and reliability of data that is stored in the database. 

There are four types of data integrity:
- Row integrity
- Column integrity
- Referential integrity
- User-defined integrity

Row integrity refers to the requirement that all rows in a table must have a unique identifier. This unique identifier is the Primary Key of the table. 

The columns included in the definition of a table's PRIMARY KEY integrity constraint are called the primary key. Although it is not required, every table should have a primary key so that:
- Each row in the table can be uniquely identified
- No duplicate rows exist in the table
reference:
https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/server.111/b28318/data_int.htm#CNCPT021
http://www.geeksengine.com/database/design/data-integrity.php
https://www3.ntu.edu.sg/home/ehchua/programming/sql/Relational_Database_Design.html


Exceptions : DB2 global temporary tables and Oracle private temporary tables do not support primary keys

https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/data/library/techarticle/dm-0912globaltemptable/index.html
https://oracle-base.com/articles/18c/private-temporary-tables-18c
remediation: Check the statement and if so, add primary key.
remediationSample:
Add a primary key:
alter table SQLAMDA001_7_TBL1 add constraint SQLAMDA001_7_TBL1_PK primary key (category_name)
using index
/
sample:
The following statement should be reviewed:
create table SQLAMDA001_7_TBL1
(category_name varchar2(10) not null ,
  title        varchar2(50) null ,
  title_id     varchar2(10) null ,
  author_name  varchar2(30) null
)
/
alternativeName: Make sure to define Primary Key (PK) for your tables to enforce row integrity of data
